But Daniel was hot, he drew first and shot
This line concludes with a snare drum, which is intended to imitate the sound of the gunshot present within the line.
I’ll be better, Doc, as soon as I am able

On the first listen, this may sound like Rocky assuring the doctor that he’ll be physically better soon, but is actually a response to the doctor’s claim that Rocky is no match for the other man:

He said, “Rocky, you met your match”

In light of this, Rocky appears  telling the doctor that he’ll be better the next time he faces off against Dan, which will be as soon as he’s healed.
[Instrumental bridge]

In the Beatles original studio recording, the bridge  includes a honky tonk piano part, played by George Martin, the producer. The piano part was recorded at half-speed to create that Fisher-Price pull toy chime sound when played back at normal speed. Half-speed recording also explains what appears to be Martin’s superhuman performance on the piano.

So one day he walked into town
 Booked himself a room in the local saloon

The name of the town isn’t mentioned in the song, but Deadwood, South Dakota is a darn good candidate. It’s situated in the heart of the Black Hills on the northeast side of Central City and about ten miles west of Sturgis. In the second half of the 19th century, Deadwood was just the kind of town for the events described in this story.

And Rocky burst in, and grinning a grin
 He said, “Danny boy, this is a showdown”

A showdown is the term for a gun fight, and a popular scene in Western action films.



– Lee Marvin (left in foreground), Jimmy Stewart (kneeling at center) and John Wayne (right in background) in the movie, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

The casual disregard Rocky shows his rival by calling him “Danny boy” makes fleeting reference to the classic British folk song of the same title:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQ9W5bxJs3w
There lived a young boy named Rocky Raccoon

Rocky’s name was probably influenced by Rocky the Flying Squirrel, one of the era’s most popular cartoon characters.  Rocky & Bullwinkle’s style – folksiness as a cover for arch humor – matches well with Paul’s style in this song, too.



McCartney said his original name for the character was Rocky Sassoon, but he changed it to Raccoon because it sounded more cowboyish.

Gideon checked out, and he left it no doubt
 To help with good Rocky’s revival

While Rocky’s body recovers, he finds Christ, thanks to Gideon’s Bible. In Evangelical Christianity, a revival is a celebration to recover and revive lost souls.

Gideon’s Bible is the name of the Bible found in hotels across the U.S. The joke here is that Rocky believes Gideon is a living person who recently checked out — but left a Bible to help the next person who stayed in the room.

There’s great wordplay going on here as well. To “check out” has a meaning to leave a hotel and pay the bill, but also means to look in and see if everything is okay, and finally, it means to die. “Revival” has a meaning of becoming strong again, and it refers to Rocky’s physical and spiritual recovery.
And Rocky said, ”Doc, it’s only a scratch
Reminiscent of Mercutio’s “tis a scratch”; the ultimate underestimate in Romeo & Juliet.

Now, she and her man, who called himself Dan
 Were in the next room at the hoe-down

The word “hoedown” rhymes well with “show-down”, and it refers to a social gathering that includes folk dancing. It’s just the kind of event you’d expect in the Black Hills on a summer Saturday night.

Now the doctor came in stinking of gin
 And proceeded to lie on the table

The doctor was hammered on some nice gin.
If you’re not listening carefully, it sounds like the doctor laid Rocky down to examine him.  Nope, the doc was so hammered that he laid himself down.



McCartney got the idea for the drunken doctor from personal experience.  In his book, A Hard Day’s Write, Steve Turner quotes from Margo Bird of Apple Records:

Paul had a moped which he came off one day in May 1966. He was a bit stoned at the time and cut his mouth and chipped his tooth. The doctor that came to treat him was stinking of gin and didn’t make a very good job of the stitching which is why Paul had a nasty lump on his lip for a while.
